awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: Collaborative: Multipath TCP Side Channel Vulnerabilities and Defenses
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this project is to understand and strengthen the security of Multipath TCP (MPTCP) - an IETF standardized suite of TCP extensions that allow one MPTCP connection, consisting of multiple sub-connections between two hosts, to use multiple paths simultaneously. Even though MPTCP has been gaining momentum in being widely deployed, its security is yet to be well understood. The project is expected to raise awareness of MPTCP security and ultimately yield a foundation for MPTCP security. The study will further increase the acceptance of MPTCP as an efficient, trustworthy, and next-generation transport layer protocol, especially considering that the deployment of new protocols can always be hindered by security concerns. The results will lead to development of guidelines and specifications for MPTCP through standards organizations such as IETF.

This project aims to gain an in-depth understanding of the implicit interaction among sub-connections within an MPTCP connection, the information that can be leaked or inferred through side channels by eavesdropping such interaction, and the potential attacks on MPTCP by exploiting such leaked or inferred information. The key insight is that the current MPTCP design inherently allows an attacker eavesdropping on one path to learn information (e.g., throughput) about the sub-connections along other paths. Such seemingly benign information leakage allows an attacker to hijack the entire MPTCP connection. This project considers three general threat models: on-path only attacker, host-assisted off-path attacker, and host-assisted on-path attacker. Based on these threat models, the PIs propose to study traffic offloading/onloading and sequence number inference attacks. The PIs also plan to design and validate countermeasures and defense mechanisms for MPTCP against such threats.

por.por_cntn:
Multipath TCP (MPTCP) is an IETF standardized suite of TCP extensions that allow one MPTCP connection, consisting of multiple sub-connections, between two hosts to use multiple paths simultaneously. This parallelism capability significantly improves the throughput and reliability while maintaining the same TCP interface to applications. Although MPTCP has already been widely deployed, its security is yet to be well understood. Most studies on MPTCP have focused on performance and fairness. Limited prior work on MPTCP security exist, including flooding, hijacking, and DoS attacks, primarily discussed in RFCs. However, they did not consider the side channels introduced by the shared state across sub-connections. This project aims to gain an in-depth understanding of the implicit interaction among sub-connections within an MPTCP connection, the information that can be leaked or inferred through side channels by eavesdropping such interaction, and the potential attacks on MPTCP by exploiting such leaked or inferred information. The key insight is that the current MPTCP design inherently allows an attacker eavesdropping on one path to learn information (e.g., throughput) about the sub-connections along other paths. Such seemingly benign information leakage allows an attacker to hijack the entire MPTCP connection. This project considers three threat models: on-path only attacker, host-assisted off-path attacker, and host-assisted on-path attacker. Based on these threat models, the PIs proposed to study the following five research tasks: (1) traffic offloading attacks, (2) traffic onloading attacks, (3) on-path sequence number inference attacks, (4) host-assisted sequence number inference attacks, and (5) countermeasures and defense mechanisms.

This project has advanced the knowledge and understanding of Multipath TCP security. The fundamental concepts developed in this project have led to a much deeper understanding of Multipath TCP and its security issues. In this project, the PI's team has successfully achieved the objective of gaining an in-depth understanding of the implicit interaction among sub-connections within an MPTCP connection, the information that can be leaked or inferred through side channels by eavesdropping such interaction, and the potential attacks on MPTCP by exploiting such leaked or inferred information. They have discovered two novel practical attacks on the IETF standard MPTCP protocol: traffic diversion attacks and hijack attacks, which leverage the throughput information obtained from cross-path throughput inference. The problems of throughput inference and connection hijack are rooted in the standard IETF MPTCP specification. The presence of the global sequence number (GSN) in plain text enables throughput inference. They have implemented and validated these attacks on a real network testbed using MPTCP Linux Kernel implementation. They also confirmed that the attacks are not just an implementation problem but because of MPTCP design choices. They have also designed novel strategies to block malicious MPTCP flows that carry the traffic over multiple paths. They also designed a deep learning model to generate application protocol signatures to block malicious traffic in real-time.

The research results have been successfully published in top tier computer science venues (such as ICNP). This project has supported a number of Ph.D. students and post-docs. The results that we developed in this project has been incorporated into the graduate courses CSE 825 "Computer and Network Security". The PI has designed course projects based on this project for students to work on. The course materials help to educate the next generation of computer engineers for the nation. In addition, this project has provided new opportunities for Ph.D. students to develop their research skills as they pursue their doctoral degrees and eventual careers in academia and/or industry.
